conclusion: Determine the difference in electric potential energy of the ball at the highest point compared to point O.
The ball is subject to gravitational force mg and electric force Eq.
Let q be the charge on the ball and E be the uniform electric field.
The ball moves along a straight line at an angle θ to the direction of the electric field.
The electric force Eq acts horizontally along the field direction.
The gravitational force mg acts vertically downward.
Forces must balance in the direction of motion since the ball moves in a straight line at angle θ.
The horizontal component of the electric force Eq must balance the vertical component of the gravitational force mg sin θ.
Decompose the motion into horizontal and vertical components.
Horizontal motion: Eq cos θ; Vertical motion: mg sin θ.
Net forces along the direction of motion must balance for straight-line motion: Eq cos θ = mg sin θ.
The work done by the electric force is the change in electric potential energy.
Work W = F · d · cos θ, where F = Eq and d is the distance traveled horizontally.
Since Eq cos θ = mg sin θ, the distance d can be related to the vertical height h.
For the ball to reach the highest point, the vertical component of its initial velocity v0 sin θ is zero at the highest point.
The total mechanical energy is conserved.
At the highest point, the kinetic energy due to vertical motion is zero, so the total energy is the sum of potential energies.
Electric potential energy change ΔUe = Eq · d.
From the equilibrium condition, d = mg sin θ / (Eq cos θ).
Calculate the change in electric potential energy ΔUe = Eq · d = Eq · (mg sin θ / Eq cos θ) = mg tan θ.
The difference in electric potential energy at the highest point compared to point O is mg tan θ.
